title: How to know if your decision is right or wrong - Quora

response.answer_text: No, you cannot know. There is absolutely no golden rule which helps you make the right decisions all the time. The only way to find out is to actually make a decision and see how it turns out. Life always goes on by taking risks. You cannot avoid this risk in life and there is no way out. However, there is one trick which you can follow. You can make an informed decision. The best you can do is to predict the consequences and then judge for yourself. The first step is understand that decisions are based on what you know at the moment of making the decisions.  Here are certain things I do for informed decision making -  Note down exactly what the decision is. Form a question in your mind with limited choices and pose this as a question. "Should I accept this job, or should I not?"; "Should I break-up with him, or should I not?"; "Should I buy this phone, or should I not?" It is important to know exactly what decision you need to make. Don't leave open ended questions like "I like her but I wonder if she is the right girl"; "This job is nice, but wouldn't it be better if I had more money!"Write the consequences of both sides. Understand the implications correctly. Have a thorough clarity of all the aspects of both the choices. It is important to understand that decisions in life are based on the given information. Hence, if you take time to understand the implications and give it a thought, you are more likely to make the correct choice.Make a decision by picking one. This is the most critical thing. We must understand that we cannot have everything and that life is essentially a compromise. Choose one over the other based on the information available to you. Make a rational decision based on your experience, knowledge, impulse, wit - anything you prefer. But remember - choose one.Don't mull over a decision once made. If you have decided something, stick with it until new information is available. This is a very critical thing to understand. As long as you have made a decision, don't keep thinking about it if the information has not changed. There is no point going over and over again "Have I done the right thing?"If the information has changed, revisit the decision. When you come to face with a new information (such as a better job than earlier, or a clarification of a doubt etc.), then you can revisit your decision and see if it makes sense to do something differently. Remember that this is now a new decision altogether.Have no regrets if you fail. In spite of whatever we discussed above, it is likely that a decision may not turn out as good as you thought. Don't worry. Take satisfaction in the fact that you did the best you could do at the given point in time. With a benefit of hindsight, everybody can say if a decision was right or wrong - but that's meaningless because making a decision is about at the moment of deciding.  The basic thing to understand is that all decisions are at a particular point in time and with a given information. If any of this changes, it is possible that the decision would have been different. However, the next time you think back and realise you made a wrong decision, always ask yourself "Was this the best I could have done at that time and with the information I had then" If yes, you've made the correct decision. No need to regret it.  This is how life is - full of decisions. Over time, you get better at it and ultimately you have a knack of making the correct decisions. But this will happen with experience. However, the basic essense of decision making will not change.   Notice that I always say decision making and never decision taking. The reason is because an informed decision is always constructed by the person deciding it (a decision is made), and not borrowed or copied from some other person (a decision is not taken).  But whatever, the point being - make your own decisions; and accept them with grace.

What is done by him or his party is always right while what is done by the opposite party is always wrong. 3: Spiritual Person A spiritual person believes that there is nothing wrong in this world because everything happens in this world according to the will of God, who can do no wrong. There is always a right hidden in every thing what people perceive as wrong. 4: Believer A religion person believes in his God and his religion. There is only one way we can know whether we’re making the right decision. It is by trusting ourselves (our intuition/ gut feeling, our knowledge/ data, our values and our priorities). I think it’s very important that we understand the difference between knowing whether we’re making the right decision (we can’t know the outcome so we have to find a different way to evaluate our move) and knowing whether we made the right decision (when we tend to judge our actions based on the outcomes they produce). The question is not How will I know that I made the right decision? (looking back on the situation), but How will I know that I’m making the right decision? (while making it). This distinction is super important because analyzing things looking back on them is usually not the same as pondering our move at the very time when we’re making this move. If we want to base our judgement on the outcome, it’s pretty obvious that we can do it only after the action has been taken (and sometimes we have to wait quite a long time). There is no way we can predict/ know in advance whether our actions (which follow our decisions) are the ones which will produce the favorable outcomes. I mean, sometimes we can (when it’s not very complicated), but important life situations tend to be more complex. We can do something thinking that we are making the right decision but it can turn out later that there was something we didn’t take into account, some important data. We simply overlooked it (because we were biased) or we couldn’t possibly have known about it (the circumstances have changed). And even when we look at the outcome immediately after we made the decision and we conclude that is wasn’t the right decision (because the outcome is undesirable), it may happen that a day/ week/ month / year, or even years, later we will change our mind and think about this decision differently. For instance, we will see how this seemingly wrong decision actually led to a whole avalanche of desirable things that happened later. Or that the decision which appeared to be right at the first glance proved wrong/ fatal when we looked at the bigger picture later. So paradoxically, it’s much easier actually to know whether we’re making the right decision (when we can’t possibly know the outcome and thus we have to evaluate our move regardless of the outcome), than it is to know whether we made the right decision (looking back and trying to evaluate the decision based on the outcome). In order to know whether we’re making the right decision all we need to do is trust ourselves (our intuition/ gut feeling, our knowledge/ data, our values and our priorities). And to find out whether we made the right decision sometimes we need to wait many years, because our initial evaluation/ conclusion may be premature. So it might be a good idea (healthy way of looking at our actions) to evaluate each our decision (the one we’re making right now, as well as the one we made in the past) the way we’d evaluate a decision at the very time when it is being made.

Great question! Some really great answers given already, so my two-pence might be redundant or repetitive. A great challenge demands for great players. Often we do not know what the future will bring. How do you know if you have made a bad decision? Usually, we get upset upon making wrong turns. But should we rely on our emotions? Remember the times when feeling good did not result in a positive outcome. So who knows better than you, if decision X is right or wrong? The right decision will be meaningful to you and your family, and maybe even society at large, today and day after. (borrowed from Jordan Peterson’s book “12 rules for life” - helped me with my decision making for sure). Think about your values. Here is an example: sharing food with a starving person on the street can be seen as right (helping ones in trouble) and wrong (you are not helping them to be independent), also it can be ignored totally. For now, let us forget the ignorant ones, and concentrate only on good and bad cases. So, you have decided it is right to share food and you did. Who can take that moment of proud away from you? And will you act the same way next time? Sometime later, you have learned it was a wrong decision, while the homeless man you have shared food with was a thief, who went and stole something from you that night. So you caught the thief and now you recognize it was the same person who you shared your food with. What can you learn from that? Most probably you will regret doing favors. And yes, the decision was wrong, but it was wrong to go to steal, rather than to share food with a hungry person. If you are alive and have learned something from your decision, then probably it was not a bad decision after all. After all, we are only humans, who can learn or not. And then you can think of millions of decisions people have made and their outcomes. Think of someone who decided to conform, instead of being themselves. Think of decisions: changing a job, moving to another country, finding career or education direction, setting personal goals. Some of them might be wrong, and we need those to understand the good ones. To conclude: Decisions help us discard the unnecessary options and to concentrate on the better options more efficiently. Deciding upon things that bring meaning and are consulted with your values should make it more stable, more real, more solid, and more lasting. I hope this helps, Kind regards, A.

I thought about this a lot last night. If a decision has a clear set of actions attached to it you can be certain you are fully responsible for anticipating the possible consequences. If a decision has a less obvious sequence of actions and less predictable range of consequences then you can only take responsibility for the end result, own it, and move on from there. A decision was “wrong” if you don't like where it took you or if it carried you somewhere you never imagined. Part of the fun of getting older is life becomes like Groundhog Day. Mostly repetitive but with opportunities to tweak and adjust things. So for example, trying a different route to work and home again, or making your coffee slightly differently, or buying a new jar of sauce you've never heard of for making dinner. The big stuff can become like our own personal moral code but even that should be flexible according to our needs. I gave up smoking for five solid years and then started again. I am very happy with both those decisions and believe each decision was correct for the context of each moment in my life. If a decision feels wrong, don't ignore it but don't beat yourself up over it. Just figure out your next steps. One of the most valuable church sermons I ever attended described our conscience like the dashboard of a car. Seatbelt light goes nuts, you fasten your belt. Oil light goes on, you plan a time to top up the oil. Radiator overheating? Fill that up and check for leaks. Or you can just smash all your dashboard lights with a hammer and drive until the car breaks down.

It can sometimes be tricky to know whether you made the right decision. Some questions you can ask are : Did you achieve the desired outcome by making the decision you made? If you hurt someone unnecessarily by the decision you made, it may not have been the right one. However, sometimes this can’t be avoided. For instance, if you were in a relationship with someone who was bad for you and you made the decision to break up with them. This was probably the right decision even though the other person may have been hurt. Is the decision in line with your morals? How do you feel about the decision? You can’t base everything off of feelings, but sometimes this can be a good question to ask. Being a christian, one thing that guides my decision making is the Bible. I try to make sure that the decisions I make are in line with my biblical values, and if they are not I know I did not make the right decision. However, the Bible isn’t black and white about every decision and in these cases I try to go with my conscious.

Very easy. Monitor the result of that decision (action). What does the world look like now? Did you achieve the goal you set out to achieve when you made the decision. In other words do you now think the world is the way you wanted to see it. If you achieved the goal, good for you, it was the right decision. If you didn’t then it was the wrong decision. I know some people will argue that you can make the “right decision” and still not end up where you want to be. Now I would ask you to define what you actually mean by “the right decision.” If you end up in the wrong place, I can accept that you “thought” it was the right decision, but in reality it wasn’t (what was “right” about it). Therefore, there would to be a logical disconnect in the argument for me. There is a large literature on Perceptual Control Theory (not a crank literature I would hasten to add, but a well constructed theoretical position) that suggests all decision making is part of a closed loop system. We are goal driven, we compare our goal with our understanding of how our world is (our perception…not necessarily reality), and if there is a difference, we form some action (decision) that is aimed at making our world match our goal. If our first action doesn’t succeed, we modify our decision in the direction we think will achieve our goals, and continue until we either succeed in achieving the goal, or we give up because the cost is too high. Sometimes we try to control things that are not in our locus of control. You will never control that loop, so move on (world peace may be one such goal). Now let’s talk about your goals. I make take issue with what you were trying to achieve, but that is a whole different argument.

It would help to clear any confusions so that we all come to the same understanding. The question involves our perception of right or wrong. In the traditional world, no two people would agree on every single issue involving what is right and what is wrong. So, we need to first formulate a scenario where everybody agrees and accepts what is right, and what is wrong. If we do that, then the rest of the answer is already made available, because we all will do the right thing and avoid the wrong thing. The right and wrong are always from a single perspective. A hungry lion killing and eating a deer is right for the lion and wrong for the deer because the deer is willing to live and not die. If after a long chase, the lion is unable to catch the deer, it is wrong for the hungry lion because he has two more kids to feed who will die of hunger. But the same situation is right for the deer who gets what he needs - a life. First learning from this situation of opposing forces in action leads us to a simple fact. Our decision of right and wrong is from our angle. We should not bring confusion and conflict by bringing in other people’s perspective. This will result in an endless confusion between conflicting rights and wrongs.What is right? What is wrong?A person is hungry. Eating food is right.A person is hungry. Not eating food is wrong.A person is in pain. Removing the pain or running away from pain is right.A person is not in pain. Going towards pain is wrong.A right or wrong is simply what is in direction of ‘life’. Any action that the life wants naturally is right. Any action that opposes life forces is wrong. There is nothing right in right or wrong in wrong. They both are essential features of life sustaining to keep itself running. Whichever is stronger wins for that particular situation. In the end, a harmony of rights and wrong is the nature of the universe.So, how do you know your decision is right or wrong? Why do you care? You just do what is needed to be done in any moment. Then on the next moment, just do again what is needed in that moment, and don’t worry about the quality of decision that you took in the past moment, because by nature, that is always going to be ‘RIGHT’!

For decisions that are irreversible, and involve any meaningful stakes and some degree of uncertainty or risk, the answer is that you can never be sure that you have made the “right” decision. If “right” corresponds to some desired outcome, then the uncertainty you face renders the “right” decision unknowable at the time you make it. However, you can be confident, in most circumstances, of making a good decision. A good decision is one where the decision-maker has made an effort to apply principles of decision quality to his or her decision-making process. In short, these principles are 1) framing the decision appropriately, 2) generating a set of creative and compelling alternatives to consider, 3) seeking out reliable and unbiased data that informs these alternatives, 4) conducting a rigorous and logical analyses of the alternatives, 5) selecting an alternative (or a hybrid of multiple alternatives) that maximizes your value measure of choice and 6) committing to the actions necessary to realize the value of your decision. Following these principles will help you achieve the highest quality decision possible. Bear in mind, however, that a good decision does not - cannot - guarantee a good outcome. A good (high quality) decision can only increase the likelihood thst the outcome you experience is a good one.

The same question was put by Arjuna to Lord Krishna in the Gita, “Why I am forced to do the sin even though I do not want to do the sin (Anichchannapi…balaadiva…)?” Before explaining the answer given by the Lord, I will give some initial clarification. When one throws a big stone on a person and kills him, the middle process of killing by stone, which is 2, is inert process only because even a stone slipping from the hill by force of wind falling on a person kills him in the same way and here, there is no agent of awareness. But when a person throws a stone with intention to kill somebody, the intention initiating the inert process is related to awareness. Subsequently, the fruit of sin given as punishment by death-sentence pains the killer and hence, the enjoyment of fruit is again related to awareness only. Therefore, the sin starting with 1 and ending by 3 is totally related to the awareness only. This awareness is stored in the soul in the form of several impressions of thoughts of violence existing as a specific functional mode called as chittam (one of the four internal instrumental modes of awareness).
